column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|Notes|label
#Text=Justice ALITO delivered the opinion of the Court .

#Text=The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 ( ERISA ) requires plaintiffs with " actual knowledge " of an alleged fiduciary breach to file suit within three years of gaining that knowledge rather than within the 6 - year period that would otherwise apply .

column1: #Text=§ 413(a)(2)(A ) , 88 Stat . 889 , as amended , 29 U.S.C. § 1113 .
#Text=The question here is whether a plaintiff necessarily has " actual knowledge " of the information contained in disclosures that he receives but does not read or can not recall reading .

column3:
*[4]	Direct Quote[4]	
4-11	441-447	actual	*[4]|*[5]	Direct Quote[4]|Focal Term[5]

4-13	458-459

column1: #Text=We hold that he does not and therefore affirm .
#Text=I
#Text=A

#Text=Retirement plans governed by ERISA must have at least one named fiduciary , § 1102(a)(1 ) , who must manage the plan prudently and solely in the interests of participants and their beneficiaries , § 1104(a ) .
#Text=Fiduciaries who breach these duties are personally liable to the plan for any resulting losses .
#Text=ERISA authorizes participants and their beneficiaries , as well as co - fiduciaries and the Secretary of Labor , to sue for that relief .
#Text=Such suits must be filed within one of three time periods , each with different triggering events .
#Text=The first begins when the breach occurs .

#Text=Specifically , under § 1113(1 ) , suit must be filed within six years of " the date of the last action which constituted a part of the breach or violation " or , in cases of breach by omission , " the latest date on which the fiduciary could have cured the breach or violation . "

#Text=We have referred to § 1113(1 ) as a statute of repose , which " effect[s ] a legislative judgment that a defendant should be free from liability after the legislatively determined period of time . "

column1: #Text=California Public Employees ' Retirement System v. ANZ Securities , Inc. , 582 U.S. ---- , ---- , 137 S.Ct . 2042 , 2049 , 198 L.Ed.2d 584 ( 2017 ) ( internal quotation marks omitted ) .
#Text=The second period , which accelerates the filing deadline , begins when the plaintiff gains " actual knowledge " of the breach .

column1: #Text=Under § 1113(2 ) , suit must be filed within three years of " the earliest date on which the plaintiff had actual knowledge of the breach or violation . "
#Text=Section 1113(2 ) is a statute of limitations , which " encourage[s ] plaintiffs to pursue diligent prosecution of known claims . "

column1: #Text=Id. , at ---- , 137 S.Ct . , at 2049 ( internal quotation marks omitted ) .
#Text=The third period , which applies " in the case of fraud or concealment , " begins when the plaintiff discovers the alleged breach .
#Text=In such cases , suit must be filed within six years of " the date of discovery . "
#Text=Ibid .
#Text=B
#Text=Respondent Sulyma worked at Intel Corporation from 2010 to 2012 .
#Text=He participated in two Intel retirement plans , the Intel Retirement Contribution Plan and the Intel 401(k ) Savings Plan .
#Text=Payments into these plans were in turn invested in two funds managed by the Intel Investment Policy Committee .
#Text=These funds mostly comprised stocks and bonds .
#Text=After the stock market decline in 2008 , however , the committee increased the funds ' shares of alternative assets , such as hedge funds , private equity , and commodities .
#Text=These assets carried relatively high fees .
#Text=And as the stock market rebounded , Sulyma 's funds lagged behind others such as index funds .

#Text=Sulyma filed this suit on behalf of a putative class in October 2015 , alleging primarily that the committee and other plan administrators ( petitioners here ) had breached their fiduciary duties by overinvesting in alternative assets .
#Text=Petitioners countered that the suit was untimely under § 1113(2 ) .
#Text=Although Sulyma filed it within six years of the alleged breaches , he filed it more than three years after petitioners had disclosed their investment decisions to him .
#Text=ERISA and its implementing regulations mandate various disclosures to plan participants .
#Text=See generally 29 U.S.C. § § 1021 - 1031 ; see also Gobeille v. Liberty Mut . Ins . Co. , 577 U.S. ---- , ---- - ---- , 136 S.Ct . 936 , 944 , 194 L.Ed.2d 20 ( 2016 ) .
#Text=Sulyma received numerous disclosures while working at Intel , some explaining the extent to which his retirement plans were invested in alternative assets .

#Text=In November 2011 , for example , he received an e - mail informing him that a Qualified Default Investment Alternative ( QDIA ) notice was available on a website called NetBenefits , where many of his disclosures were hosted .
#Text=See App . 149 - 151 ; see also 29 CFR § § 2550 .404c-5(b ) - ( d ) ( 2019 ) ( QDIA
#Text=notices ) ; § 2520.104b-1(c ) ( regulating electronic disclosure ) .
#Text=This notice broke down the percentages at which his 401(k ) fund was invested in stocks , bonds , hedge funds , and commodities .
#Text=See App . 236 .

#Text=In 2012 , he received a summary plan description explaining that the funds were invested in stocks and alternative assets , i d . , at 227 , and referring him to other documents - called fund fact sheets - with the percentages in graphical form .

#Text=See 29 U.S.C. § § 1022 , 1024(b ) ( summary plan descriptions ) ; see also App . 307 ( June 2012 fact sheet for his 401(k ) plan fund ) ; i d . , at 338 ( June 2012 fact sheet for his retirement contribution plan fund ) ; i d . , at 277 - 340 ( other fact sheets provided during his tenure at Intel ) .

#Text=Also in 2012 , he received e - mails directing him to annual disclosures that petitioners provided for both his plans , which showed the underlying funds ' return rates and again directed him to the NetBenefits site for further information .
#Text=See 29 CFR § 2550 .404a-5 ; see also App . 242 - 243 ( retirement contribution plan annual disclosure ) ; i d . , at 250 - 251 ( 401(k ) plan annual disclosure ) .
#Text=Petitioners submitted records showing that Sulyma visited the NetBenefits site repeatedly during his employment .
#Text=I d . , at 258 - 276 .
#Text=But he testified in his deposition that he did not " remember reviewing " the above disclosures during his tenure .

column1: #Text=I d . , at 175 ; see also i d . , at 183 , 193 , 196 - 197 .

#Text=He also stated in a declaration that he was " unaware " while working at Intel " that the monies that [ he ] had invested through the Intel retirement plans had been invested in hedge funds or private equity . "
#Text=I d . , at 212 .

#Text=He recalled reviewing only account statements sent to him by mail , which directed him to the NetBenefits site and noted that his plans were invested in " short - term / other " assets but did not specify which .
#Text=See , e.g. , i d . , at 375 .

#Text=The District Court granted summary judgment to petitioners under § 1113(2 ) , reasoning that " [ i]t would be improper to allow Sulyma 's claims to survive merely because he did not look further into the disclosures made to him . "
#Text=The Ninth Circuit reversed .
#Text=As relevant here , the court construed " actual knowledge " to mean " what it says : knowledge that is actual , not merely a possible inference from ambiguous circumstances . "

column1: #Text=909 F.3d 1069 , 1076 ( 2018 ) ( internal quotation marks omitted ) .

#Text=Although Sulyma " had sufficient information available to him to know about the allegedly imprudent investments " more than three years before filing suit , the court held that his testimony created a dispute as to when he actually gained that knowledge .

column1: #Text=Id. , at 1077 .
#Text=Several Circuits have likewise construed § 1113(2 ) to require " knowledge that is actual , " i d. , at 1076 , but one has construed it to require only proof of sufficient disclosure .

#Text=We granted certiorari , 587 U.S. ---- , 139 S.Ct . 2692 , 204 L.Ed.2d 1089 ( 2019 ) , to resolve whether the phrase " actual knowledge " does in fact mean " what it says , " 909 F.3d at 1076 , and hold that it does .

column1: #Text=II
#Text=A
#Text=" We must enforce plain and unambiguous statutory language " in ERISA , as in any statute , " according to its terms . "

column1: #Text=Dictionaries are hardly necessary to confirm the point , but they do .
#Text=When Congress passed ERISA , the word " actual " meant what it means today : " existing in fact or reality . "

column1: #Text=The qualifier " actual " creates that distinction .
#Text=In everyday speech , " actual knowledge " might seem redundant ; one who claims " knowledge " of a topic likely means to suggest that he actually knows a thing or two about it .

column1: #Text=But the law will sometimes impute knowledge - often called " constructive " knowledge - to a person who fails to learn something that a reasonably diligent person would have learned .
#Text=See i d . , at 1043 .

#Text=Similarly , we held in Merck & Co. v. Reynolds , 559 U.S. 633 , 130 S.Ct . 1784 , 176 L.Ed.2d 582 ( 2010 ) , that the word " discovery , " when used in a statute of limitations without qualification , " encompasses not only those facts the plaintiff actually knew , but also those facts a reasonably diligent plaintiff would have known . "
#Text=The addition of " actual " in § 1113(2 ) signals that the plaintiff 's knowledge must be more than " potential , possible , virtual , conceivable , theoretical , hypothetical , or nominal . "
#Text=Black 's Law Dictionary 53 ( 4th ed . 1951 ) .

#Text=Indeed , in Merck , we cited § 1113(2 ) as evidence of the " linguistic distinction " between " ' actual knowledge ' " and the " hypothetical " knowledge that a reasonably diligent plaintiff would have .

column1: #Text=559 U.S. at 646 - 647 , 130 S.Ct . 1784 ( quoting § 1113(2 ) ; emphasis in original ) .
#Text=Congress has drawn the same distinction elsewhere in ERISA .

#Text=Multiple provisions contain alternate 6 - year and 3 - year limitations periods , with the 6 - year period beginning at " the date on which the cause of action arose " and the 3 - year period starting at " the earliest date on which the plaintiff acquired or should have acquired actual knowledge of the existence of such cause of action . "

#Text=ERISA also requires plaintiffs challenging the suspension of benefits under § 1085 to do so within " one year after the earliest date on which the plaintiff acquired or should have acquired actual knowledge of the existence of such cause of action . "
#Text=Thus , Congress has repeatedly drawn a " linguistic distinction " between what an ERISA plaintiff actually knows and what he should actually know .

column1: #Text=Merck , 559 U.S. at 647 , 130 S.Ct . 1784 .
#Text=And when Congress has included both forms of knowledge in a provision limiting ERISA actions , it has done so explicitly .
#Text=We can not assume that it meant to do so by implication in § 1113(2 ) .
#Text=Instead we " generally presum[e ] that Congress acts intentionally and purposely when it includes particular language in one section of a statute but omits it in another . "

column1: #Text=BFP v. Resolution Trust Corporation , 511 U.S. 531 , 537 , 114 S.Ct . 1757 , 128 L.Ed.2d 556 ( 1994 ) ( internal quotation marks omitted ) .

#Text=Petitioners dispute the characterization of anything less than actual knowledge as constructive knowledge , arguing that the latter term usually refers to information that a plaintiff must seek out rather than information that is sent to him .
#Text=But if a plaintiff is not aware of a fact , he does not have " actual knowledge " of that fact however close at hand the fact might be .
#Text=And Congress has never added to § 1113(2 ) the language it has used in other ERISA limitations provisions to encompass both what a plaintiff actually knows and what he reasonably could know .
#Text=As presently written , therefore , § 1113(2 ) requires more than evidence of disclosure alone .
#Text=That all relevant information was disclosed to the plaintiff is no doubt relevant in judging whether he gained knowledge of that information .
#Text=See Part III , infra .
#Text=To meet § 1113(2 ) 's " actual knowledge " requirement , however , the plaintiff must in fact have become aware of that information .
#Text=B
#Text=Petitioners offer arguments for a broader reading of § 1113(2 ) based on text , context , purpose , and statutory history .
#Text=All founder on Congress 's choice of the word " actual . "
#Text=As for text , petitioners do not dispute the normal definitions of " actual , " " knowledge , " or " actual knowledge . "
#Text=They focus instead on the least conspicuous part of the phrase " had actual knowledge " : the word " had . "
#Text=Once a plaintiff receives a disclosure , they argue , he " ha[s ] " the knowledge that § 1113(2 ) requires because he effectively holds it in his hand .
#Text=Ibid .
#Text=In other words , he has the requisite knowledge because he could acquire it with reasonable effort .
#Text=That turns § 1113(2 ) into what it is plainly not : a constructive - knowledge requirement .
#Text=Petitioners ' contextual argument fails for the same reason .
#Text=As they point out , ERISA 's disclosure regime is meant to " ensur[e ] that ' the individual participant knows exactly where he stands with respect to the plan . ' "
#Text=Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. v. Bruch , 489 U.S. 101 , 118 , 109 S.Ct . 948 , 103 L.Ed.2d 80 ( 1989 ) ( quoting H.R. Rep. No . 93 - 533 , p. 11 ( 1973 ) ) .
#Text=This is the reason for ERISA 's requirements that disclosures be written for a lay audience .
#Text=See , e.g. , 29 U.S.C. § 1022 ( a ) .
#Text=Once plan administrators satisfy their obligations to impart knowledge , petitioners say , § 1113(2 ) 's knowledge requirement is satisfied too .
#Text=But that is simply not what § 1113(2 ) says .
#Text=Unlike other ERISA limitations periods - which also form § 1113(2 ) 's context- § 1113(2 ) begins only when a plaintiff actually is aware of the relevant facts , not when he should be .
#Text=And a given plaintiff will not necessarily be aware of all facts disclosed to him ; even a reasonably diligent plaintiff would not know those facts immediately upon receiving the disclosure .

#Text=Although " the words of a statute must be read in their context , " Davis v. Michigan Dept . of Treasury , 489 U.S. 803 , 809 , 109 S.Ct . 1500 , 103 L.Ed.2d 891 ( 1989 ) , petitioners ' argument again gives the word " actual " little meaning at all .

column1: #Text=Petitioners also argue that § 1113(2 ) 's plain meaning undermines its purpose of protecting plan administrators from suits over bygone investment decisions .
#Text=If a plan participant can simply deny knowledge , they say , administrators will rarely get the benefit of § 1113(2 ) .
#Text=But even if this is true , as it may well be , we can not say that heeding the clear meaning of the word " actual " renders the statute so " ' [ in]coherent ' "

column1: #Text=that it must be disregarded .
#Text=Kingdomware Technologies , Inc. v. United States , 579 U.S. ---- , ---- , 136 S.Ct . 1969 , 1976 , 195 L.Ed.2d 334 ( 2016 ) .
#Text=For one thing , plan participants are not the only potential plaintiffs subject to § 1113 .
#Text=The Secretary of Labor , for example , may also sue imprudent fiduciaries for the benefit of plan participants .

#Text=And the United States represents that the Secretary will have a hard time doing so within § 1113(2 ) 's timeframe if deemed to have actual knowledge of the facts contained in the many reports that the Department receives from ERISA plans each year .
#Text=See Brief for United States as Amicus Curiae 27 - 28 .
#Text=Moreover , the statute 's repose period will still protect defendants from suits filed more than six years after the alleged breach .

#Text=Petitioners may well be correct that heeding the plain meaning of § 1113(2 ) substantially diminishes the protection that it provides for ERISA fiduciaries , but by the same token , petitioners ' interpretation would greatly reduce § 1113(1 ) 's value for beneficiaries , given the disclosure regime that petitioners themselves emphasize .
#Text=Choosing between these alternatives is a task for Congress , and we must assume that the language of § 1113(2 ) reflects Congress 's choice .
#Text=If policy considerations suggest that the current scheme should be altered , Congress must be the one to do it .
#Text=See , e.g. , Azar v. Allina Health Services , 587 U.S. ---- , ---- , 139 S.Ct . 1804 , 1813 , 204 L.Ed.2d 139 ( 2019 ) .
#Text=Finally , petitioners argue that the plain meaning of " actual knowledge " renders an earlier version of § 1113(2 ) incoherent .

column1: #Text=As originally enacted , the § 1113(2 ) limitations period began either when the plaintiff gained actual knowledge of the alleged breach or when " a report from which [ the plaintiff ] could reasonably be expected to have obtained knowledge ... was filed with " the Secretary of Labor .
#Text=That latter , constructive - knowledge clause was later repealed .
#Text=See Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987 , § 9342(b ) , 101 Stat . 1330 -371 .

#Text=According to petitioners , if " actual knowledge " means what it says , then the original version of § 1113(2 ) charged plan participants with learning what was sent to the Secretary but not what was sent to them .
#Text=The version at issue here , however , is the current one - from which Congress removed any mention of constructive knowledge .
#Text="

column3:
*	Direct Quote	

#Text=When Congress acts to amend a statute , we presume it intends its amendment to have real and substantial effect .

column1: #Text=Plaintiffs who recall reading particular disclosures will of course be bound by oath to say so in their depositions .
#Text=On top of that , actual knowledge can be proved through " inference from circumstantial evidence . "
#Text=Ibid . ; see also Staples v. United States , 511 U.S. 600 , 615 - 616 , n. 11 , 114 S.Ct . 1793 , 128 L.Ed.2d 608 ( 1994 ) ( " [ K]nowledge can be inferred from circumstantial evidence " ) .

#Text=Evidence of disclosure would no doubt be relevant , as would electronic records showing that a plaintiff viewed the relevant disclosures and evidence suggesting that the plaintiff took action in response to the information contained in them .

#Text=And though , " [ a]t the summary judgment stage , facts must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party , " that is true " only if there is a ' genuine ' dispute as to those facts . "
#Text=Scott v. Harris , 550 U.S. 372 , 380 , 127 S.Ct . 1769 , 167 L.Ed.2d 686 ( 2007 ) ( quoting Fed . Rule Civ . Proc . 56(c ) ) .

#Text=If a plaintiff 's denial of knowledge is " blatantly contradicted by the record , " " a court should not adopt that version of the facts for purposes of ruling on a motion for summary judgment . "
#Text=Today 's opinion also does not preclude defendants from contending that evidence of " willful blindness " supports a finding of " actual knowledge . "
#Text=Cf . Global - Tech Appliances , Inc. v. SEB S. A. , 563 U.S. 754 , 769 , 131 S.Ct . 2060 , 179 L.Ed.2d 1167 ( 2011 ) .
#Text=In the case before us , however , petitioners do not argue that " actual knowledge " is established in any of these ways , only that they need not offer any such proof .
#Text=And that is incorrect .
#Text=* * *
#Text=For these reasons , we affirm .
#Text=It is so ordered .
